title: Library fails to build when compiler warnings are emitted
body:
### Description
Spdlog currently sets the compiler option `-Wfatal-errors` unconditionally to its library target via the [`spdlog_enable_warnings` ](https://github.com/gabime/spdlog/blob/v1.x/CMakeLists.txt#L159) CMake function. This makes it difficult to locally build the library from source, especially when used as Git Submodule. For example, when building the latest version v1.5.0, Clang-6.0 (available on Ubuntu 18.04 LTS) issues the warning reported in #1488 that produces a fatal error. The warnings are not enabled for the header-only CMake target, but the [`README.md`](https://github.com/gabime/spdlog#static-lib-version-recommended---much-faster-compile-times) specifically recommends using the library target for faster compile times:

> #### Static lib version (recommended - much faster compile times)

While building a library without warnings is an important goal for developers, this information is not really useful for downstream users. And with `-Wfatal-errors`, it can actually cause trouble. Could all warning flags be conditionally set, e.g., via a CMake option?

### Suggestions
* Add CMake option `SPDLOG_ENABLE_WARNINGS` (default: `OFF`) for controlling the warnings on the `spdlog` library target.
* Remove `-Wfatal-errors` from the "regular warnings" flag list.
* Recommend linking to header-only target if spdlog is used as submodule (if previous suggestions are not feasible for some reason)
